At-a-Glance: Systematic renewal of old brood comb reduces pathogen/pesticide residues and improves brood health.
Why it Matters: Dark, heavily used comb harbours spores and residues; rotating frames maintains cleaner brood nests and clearer pheromone signalling.
Step-by-Step: Mark frames by year; each season, move darkest brood frames to edges and replace with foundation near the nest centre; melt/sterilise retired comb; target 1/3 renewal per year so all brood comb is <3 years old.
Seasonality & Climate: Do renewals during strong nectar flows to speed drawing; avoid heavy rewiring or large swaps in cold weather.
Common Pitfalls: Letting ‘just one more season’ accumulate; moving brood too far from the cluster; missing labels and losing track.
Tools & Materials: Frame labelling system, spare foundation, rendering/sterilisation setup, and simple rotation logs.
